ygData.subject: Concentration Game
ygData.msgSnippet: I m making real progress on the concentration evolver. It now evolves ANNs that are much better than a random player!  This game requires active use of memory

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=104426122
X-Yahoo-Profile: zenguyuno

I'm making real progress on the concentration evolver.
 It now evolves ANNs that are much better than a
random player!  This game requires active use of
memory during the game.  All of the previous ANNs that
I've worked with were essentially ROMs; the evolution
was all for the purpose of programming the ROM. 
Concentration cannot be played effectively by ROM
alone; it requires active use of RAM.  I chose this
problem knowing that it was well suited for a Von
Neuman or Turing machine, not for your typical ANN. 
But I'm using a type of ANN that is a state machine,
and has some RAM capability.  I was not at all sure if
it could play the concentration game, and neither were
a couple of experts I talked to, so I'm very pleased
with this success.

The "deck" that I've been using has only these six
cards: 1 1 2 2 3 3, so its a pretty small game.  I
plan eventually to use a larger deck.

The ANN is a fully connected binary threshold machine,
or Hopfield network.
To make clear what this means I'll describe completely
a 2 neuron version with one input and one output.

Each neuron is a summer and a unit step function:

	y1 = U(w11*y1 + w12*y2 - T1 + wx*x)
        y2 = U(w21*y1 + w22*y2 - T2)

U(x) is the unit step function which is 0 for negative
x and 1 otherwise.
y1 and y2 are the states of the neurons
y1 is also the external output
x is the external input
The w's are weights and the T's are thresholds.  They
are what get evolved, starting with random values.

for my concentration player I'm using 15 neurons with
18 inputs and six outputs, but it follows exactly the
plan above, just with a lot more terms.

The way this is computed is, we start with y1 and y2,
then we compute everything without changing y1 and y2,
and then y1 and y2 are given new values.  That is one
step.  This can be repeated through several steps;
after a few steps it will either stabilize or enter a
limit cycle which persists forever.  When playing the
game, I allow it to step until there is exactly one
high output, which selects the card to turn over.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
